questions.question_text: When an SDN-based model is used to transmit multimedia traffic, which aspect should an architect consider while designing the network?

discussion.content:
Flow forwarding is a core concept of SDN, where the SDN controller dynamically manages and directs the flow of packets based on network policies. For multimedia traffic, precise control over forwarding paths ensures that real-time data (like video or voice) is prioritized to minimize latency, jitter, and packet loss.
QoE estimation (B) is important for evaluating user experience but is more of a monitoring task rather than a design concern.

Selected Answer: B
When designing a network for transmitting multimedia traffic using an SDN-based model, an architect should consider the aspect of QoE estimation (Quality of Experience).

QoE estimation refers to the measurement and assessment of the perceived quality of multimedia content by end users. In the context of SDN, it involves evaluating the quality of multimedia traffic in real-time and making decisions based on that assessment to ensure optimal user experience.

questions.question_text: A customer has a functional requirement that states HR systems within a data center should be segmented from other systems that reside in the same data center and same VLAN. The systems run legacy applications by using hard-coded IP addresses with all HR systems dedicated to .129 to .254 of the 10.20.20.0/24 prefix. Which segmentation method is optimal for the customer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
VLAN (Virtual LAN) is a concept in which we divide the broadcast domain into smaller broadcast domains logically at layer 2. If we create different VLANs then by default, a host from one VLAN can communicate with all the hosts residing in the same VLAN. If we want some hosts not able to reach other hosts within the same VLAN, then the concept of VLAN Access-list or Private VLAN can be used.

Selected Answer: B

Answer is D: Increased Convergence Time: Policy-based routing can complicate the routing process because it allows for routing decisions based on policies other than the standard routing table. During network reconvergence, the network must not only reestablish the best paths based on traditional routing protocols but also reapply the policies that govern PBR. This additional step can slow down the overall convergence process, leading to increased convergence time.

Given the context of the question about reconvergence and PBR, the most relevant concern is:
B. It can create microloops during reconvergence.

I choose B
Policy-based routing (PBR) can be used to implement a variety of routing policies, but it can also introduce potential problems with network reconvergence. One such problem is the possibility of creating microloops.

A microloop is a loop that is created between two or more devices in a network. Microloops can cause traffic to circulate between the devices indefinitely, which can lead to performance problems and even network outages.

Microloops can be created during reconvergence if PBR is not configured correctly. For example, if a PBR rule is configured to route traffic over a link that is down, the traffic may be looped back to the source device.

Selected Answer: A
Answer should be A

Policy-based routing adds flexibility and control that other routing techniques do not, however. It gives you a level of control that a routing protocol by itself can’t accomplish. With flexibility, there is typically a cost, and in this case, it’s scalability and manageability.

questions.question_text: Company XYZ has implemented policy-based routing in their network. Which potential problem must be kept in mind about network reconvergence and PBR?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In this design, the loopback addresses of the enterprise CE (Customer Edge) routers are the only addresses advertised to the service provider cloud network. This is achieved by utilizing MPLS to encapsulate the VPNv4 label and VPN payload, ensuring that only the loopback addresses are advertised.

The transport layer carrying the VPNv4 label and VPN payload is achieved using the MP-BGP control plane, meeting the requirement of carrying the VPNv4 label and payload over the MP-BGP control plane.

By utilizing multipoint GRE, the transport layer is not under the control of the service provider, fulfilling the requirement of the transport layer not being under service provider control.

Selected Answer: B
B. Only way the transport layer is not under service provider control is to run your own MPLS over mGRE and use MP-BGP to distribute the VPNv4 labels.
